page.title: 01BARDON MILL AND AREA
page.content: There are many small hamlets gathered along the low lying banks of the S. Tyne as it runs from W. to E. Each is serviced by the road and railway which follows the valley. None of the settlements have a shop except for Bardon Mill with its Post Office/Store but the local service station now sells some groceries. Bus and train services are two hourly so most people have to rely on car for travel to work or for shopping. Local work is farming but most inhabitants of the settlements work in the larger towns od Haltwhistle to W. and Hexham to E. There is a high proportion of professionals who commute even further. Farms, mostly sheep or cattle to fatten, arable for winter food for animals. Vindolanda Roman Fort to the N. is still being developed as tourist attraction with museum and wall
